I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Microenterprise 
Development Project.1  
 
2.  The ongoing project comprises (i) a financial intermediary loan of $50 million from the 
ordinary capital resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for a credit line implemented by 
the Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation (PKSF)—an apex development finance organization set up 
by the government—through its partner microfinance institutions (MFIs); and (ii) a technical 
assistance (TA) grant of $500,000 to support microenterprise development. The entire $50 million 
loan has been disbursed to the PKSF, which has then disbursed it to 39,580 microenterprises 
through its 77 partner organizations, with an average loan size of $1,493, generating 91,430 rural 
jobs.2 The report and recommendation of the President for the current project is accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
3.  The additional financing will scale up the ongoing project and help restore the economic 
activities of microenterprises, severely impacted by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
  
4.  The COVID-19 pandemic has severely affected the lives and livelihoods of people in 
Bangladesh. Many formal and informal workers in rural and urban areas have lost their livelihoods 
because of the pandemic and its associated economic shocks. Women have been heavily hit, as 
they  are  often  entrepreneurs  and  wage  earners  in  agriculture,  fisheries,  livestock,  small 
manufacturing, food processing, services, and trading. People living marginally above the poverty 
line are being pushed back into poverty as alternative employment opportunities are not available. 
Government support for wages to selected industry workers and cash subsidies to the urban poor, 
though  extremely  helpful  as  a  stopgap  measure,  cannot  be  sustained  over  long  periods. 
Employment generation, especially in rural areas, needs to be supported. 
 
5.  Microenterprises,  with  their  large  employment  potential,  are  ideal  for  job  creation.3 
However, they  are facing  working capital  constraints,  supply  disruptions,  and low  demand 
because of the COVID-19 economic slowdown; and their liquidity is severely constrained.4 This 
is affecting employment, production, and revenues. Women entrepreneurs who have experienced 
business losses do not have sufficient liquid assets, personal savings, or access to finance, so 
they have been forced to shut down or drastically scale down business operations.5 The PKSF

Workers: A Rapid Assessment and Quest for Recovery from Losses Induced by COVID-19 Pandemic. Dhaka.

2 
estimates that about $170 million of additional financing is needed for post-COVID-19 economic 
restoration and to meet microenterprises’ demand for working capital.6 The additional financing 
will help retain businesses and protect the employment of affected microenterprises.  
 
6.  Performance of the ongoing project. The ongoing project is performing well as (i) it is 
rated on track in the project performance rating system; (ii) safeguards are complied with; (iii) the 
delivery of expected outputs, including the implementation of the gender action plan, is rated 
successful; and (iv) risk management is rated successful, as all risks in the risk assessment and 
risk management plan have been managed successfully.7 Women borrowers comprise 78% of 
the  microenterprises  receiving  financing.  The  TA  is  supporting  the  PKSF  and  its  partner 
organizations to expand MFIs’ microenterprise development services and financing; and to pilot 
test new technology through innovative, mobile-based microenterprise financing applications.8 It 
is providing MFIs with skills for risk assessment, credit appraisal, and financial management for 
microenterprise  finance,  as  well  as  increasing  capacity  in  microenterprise  lending  by 
implementing  gender-inclusive  finance  guidelines.  The  project  is  also  strengthening 
environmental and social screening systems for the PKSF and its partner organizations. Good 
progress has been made to develop a medium-term institutional strengthening and financing 
strategy for the PKSF, including retaining its competitiveness and relevance.  
 
7.  Suitability of using the additional financing modality. The proposed project meets the 
eligibility criteria for additional financing. The overall project is (i) technically feasible, economically 
viable, and financially sound; (ii) accorded high priority by the government; (iii) consistent with the 
project’s development objective; and (iv) consistent with ADB’s country operations business plan 
for Bangladesh, 2021–2023.9 The proposed additional financing is strongly linked to the ongoing 
project’s outputs and outcome, uses the same design and implementation arrangements, and 
builds on the lessons learned and due diligence of the ongoing project. 
 
8.  Strategic context. The project is aligned with the government’s National Sustainable 
Development Strategy, 2010–2021, which promotes micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises 
to generate job opportunities.10 It is aligned with the operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 
to address remaining poverty and reduce inequalities, accelerate progress in gender equity, and 
promote rural development.11 It is also aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–
2020, which identifies improving rural livelihoods and expanding employment opportunities as key 
priority areas.12 The project will complement support from other development partners.13 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
9.  The impact and outcome of the project remain unchanged. The project is aligned with the 
following impact: growth of microenterprises expanded to provide forward linkages to agriculture 
and generate job opportunities. The project outcome is microenterprises’ access to MFI financing

increased. It will support microenterprises affected by COVID-19. The overall project focuses on 
gender equity, and targets a loan portfolio with at least 70% women borrowers.14 The project 
outputs remain unchanged, while performance indicators will be updated. The revised design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The additional financing project comprises three outputs. 
 
10.  Output 1: Funding to microfinance institutions for microenterprise loans expanded. 
This output will provide a credit line to the PKSF for relending to its partner organizations to ease 
short-term microenterprise financing constraints. It aims to provide loans to at least 30,000 
COVID-19 affected microenterprises who are eligible members of partner organizations, 70% of 
whom are female.15 The PKSF’s microenterprise total loans outstanding will be Tk24 billion, 
almost double the 2017 baseline, with at least Tk5 billion for COVID-19 affected microenterprises. 
The partner organizations’ microenterprise loan portfolio outstanding will reach Tk160 billion, 
more than double the 2017 baseline, of which at least 70% are for female borrowers. To address 
medium-term financing constraints,  a medium-term institutional strengthening  and  financing 
strategy for the PKSF was developed under the ongoing project. This is under discussion, and 
the PKSF will adopt the agreed recommendations. 
 
11.  Output 2: Microfinance institutions’ capacity in microenterprise lending enhanced. 
This  output  will  enhance MFI capacity in microenterprise  lending  by  implementing  gender-
inclusive finance guidelines, improved under the ongoing project. Training (including refresher) 
will be provided to 120 partner organizations using the microenterprise finance operational 
guidelines developed under the ongoing project. The guidelines include methodologies for the 
credit appraisal, pricing, terms and conditions, and financial and portfolio management and 
monitoring of MFIs’ microenterprise finance operations, including risk management. The mobile-
based microenterprise financing application—pilot tested for selected partner organizations for 
activities such as loan applications, appraisal, disbursement, and collection—will be extended to 
three more partner organizations and 10,000 additional microenterprise borrowers, of whom at 
least 70% are female. Legal and regulatory consultation, application development or adoption, 
guidelines and manual development, and partner organization and client training will continue. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Microfinance  institutions’  microenterprise  development  support 
extended. This output will enhance access to wider and upscale markets for an additional 1,000 
microenterprise borrowers, at least 70% of whom are women. It will expand the identification of 
another three microenterprise products for potential expansion; and support microenterprise 
cluster development by assisting in quality control, branding, packaging, and marketing. Priority 
will be given to female microenterprise borrowers. In addition, this output will extend the support 
initiated in the ongoing project for linking microenterprises to e-commerce platforms. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
13.  The proposed project will alleviate the financing needs of at least 30,000 COVID-19 
affected  microenterprises  by  providing  cheaper  financing  terms.  On  ADB’s  request,  the 
government and the PKSF have agreed to reduce the onlending rate by at least 25% (from the 
current 24% to a maximum of 18% per year). The loan will help the PKSF to leverage $35 million

Bangladesh estimates that women entrepreneurs own only 7.2% of the 8 million enterprises in Bangladesh (of which 
99.9% are small and micro). 
15 Criteria for the selection of COVID-19 affected microenterprises will be (i) microenterprises in small manufacturing, 
agriculture, fisheries, and livestock whose average operating capital decreased by 10% or more from pre-March 2020 
levels between 30 March and 30 June 2020; or (ii) microenterprises in the services sector whose average sales 
decreased by 20% or more from pre-March levels between 30 March and 30 June 2020.

4 
from commercial banks, $50 million from client savings, and $35 million from cumulative surplus 
and equity of partner organizations. At least Tk5 billion of the PKSF’s microenterprise loans 
outstanding will be for COVID-19 affected microenterprises. The additional financing will inject 
liquidity into the rural economy; and help retain businesses and jobs for microenterprises. At least 
70% of microenterprise borrowers will be female, and 90,000 jobs will be protected or created. 
ADB  financing  will  be  used  for  agriculture,  fisheries,  livestock,  small  manufacturing,  food 
processing, services, and trading, which are badly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The 
development of clusters could also help firms in the regional value chain to address supply chain 
disruptions caused by the pandemic. Moreover, the project will promote a shift in the MFI business 
model to digital transactions, which are more efficient and easier and safer for borrowers to use 
in the post-COVID-19 scenario.

15.  The government has requested a regular loan of $50 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period 
of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on the straight-line 
method, the average loan maturity is 15.25 years, and the maturity premium payable to ADB is 
0.10% per year.  
  
16.  The government will relend the ADB loan proceeds to the PKSF in local currency under a 
mutually agreed subsidiary loan agreement. The government will bear the foreign exchange risks. 
 
17.  The  PKSF  will  relend  to  selected  partner  organizations  for  financing  eligible 
microenterprise borrowers. The relending rates from the PKSF to partner organizations are 7.5% 
per year for partner organizations with loans outstanding above Tk1.0 billion; 6.0% for partner

5 
organizations  with  loans  outstanding  of  Tk0.5  billion–Tk1.0  billion;  and  5.0%  for  partner 
organizations with loans outstanding below Tk0.5 billion. PKSF loans to partner organizations will 
have a 3-year maturity, including a 6-month grace period. Loans to microenterprise borrowers 
range from Tk50,000 to Tk1 million, with a maturity of up to 2 years. The repayment schedule will 
depend on microenterprises’ cash flow pattern. The maximum interest rate for the sub-loans is 
18% per year based on a declining balance. Loans repaid by partner organizations will be 
revolved on the same terms by the PKSF.

B.  Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
20.  There are no high or substantial risks to this project. Country and entity risks have been 
assessed and described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.17 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
21.  The government and the PKSF have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement, 
as described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
22.  The government and the PKSF have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. Additional conditions for loan 
effectiveness include (i) the government and the PKSF entering into a subsidiary loan agreement, 
in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, pursuant to which the government will make available 
the Taka equivalent of the ADB loan proceeds to the PKSF; and (ii) the project management unit 
within the PKSF having been supplemented with dedicated staff for overall project management 
and the preparation of withdrawal applications as well as the consolidation and compilation of 
financial reports. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
23.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $50,000,000 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of Bangladesh  for the  additional  financing  of  the Microenterprise 
Development Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements presented to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The additional financing will scale up the ongoing project and help restore the economic activities of microenterprises, severely impacted by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2020 is provided for the ADB project 51269-002 in Bangladesh.
